journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Damage detection of unidirectional carbon fiber–reinforced laminates with embedded magnetostrictive particulates: A preliminary study

article-meta.aff: 1Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS, USA
2Air Force Research Laboratory Munitions Directorate, Flight Vehicles Integration Branch, Florida, USA

author-notes.corresp: Oliver J Myers, Mississippi State University, 219 Carpenter Hall, Box 9552, Mississippi State, MS 39762, USA. Email: myers@me.msstate.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue—ASME 2011 Conference on Smart Materials, Adaptive Structures and Intelligent Systems (SMASIS), Symposium on Enabling Technologies and Integrated System Design

abstract.p: Defects in composite laminates are difficult to detect because of the conductive and paramagnetic properties of composite materials. Timely detection of defects in composite laminates can improve reliability. This research illustrates the preliminary analysis and detection of delaminations in carbon fiber laminate beams using a single layer of magnetostrictive particles and noncontacting concentric magnetic excitation and sensing coils. The baseline analytical models also begin to address the intrusive nature of the magnetostrictive particles as well as relate the applied excitation field with the stress and magnetic flux densities induced in the magnetostrictive layer. Numerical methods are used to begin to characterize the presence of magnetostrictive particles in the laminate and the behavior of the magnetostrictive particles in relationship to the magnetic field used during sensing. Unidirectional laminates with embedded delaminations are used for simulations and experimentations. A novel, yet simplified fabrication method is discussed to ensure consistent scanning and sensing capabilities. The nondestructive evaluation scanning experiments were conducted with various shapes and sizes of damages introduced into carbon fiber–reinforced polymeric composite structures. The results demonstrate high potential for magnetostrictive particles as a low-cost, noncontacting, and reliable sensor for nondestructive evaluation of composite materials.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A chief concern with composite laminates is delamination between adjacent plies that results in weakening of the entire laminate. When a void is present, stresses in the laminate are not able to distribute evenly causing stress concentrations around the area of the void. These stress concentrations can cause the void to grow and eventually result in failure of the laminate (Edmonds and Hickman, 2000). For fiber/matrix composite materials, internal failure can result from fiber breaking, microcracking in the matrix, debonding, and delaminations (Agarwal, 2006). These defects can cause the designed properties of a composite material to degrade, which can result in premature structural failure. A dilemma with delamination is finding a way to discover when a void has developed without disassembling the laminate and studying the individual plies. A vast amount of research has been conducted to develop new ways of testing and locating delaminations in composite laminates (Chu and Yum, 2001; Petculescu et al., 2007; Tan and Tong, 2007). For example, modally selective, low-frequency, antisymmetric Lamb-wave transducers were affixed to composite specimens to determine the size and location of previously known, embedded damages. This technique was successful in sensing the damage (Petculescu et al., 2007), but made no distinction if the damage was linear or circular and was marginally successful in calculating the size of the damage. Moreover, this method requires the use of external sensors/actuators.

In the field of nondestructive evaluation (NDE), methods are developed to unobtrusively inspect and assess the integrity of structures, particularly composite materials. Of these techniques, magnetostriction-based inspections allow internal defects to be found through magnetic signature changes and also provide quantitative insight into internal stresses through constitutive magnetostrictive equations (Krishnamurthy et al., 2000). Magnetostriction is a property of materials that exhibit a mechanical strain in response to a magnetic field. The magnetostrictive material, Terfenol-D, was originally developed by the Naval Ordnance Laboratory for use in sonar applications, but the giant magnetostrictive properties of Terfenol-D allow it to be used for sensing as well as actuation applications. Magnetostrictive materials are similar to piezoelectric materials in that a strain can be induced in the material by placing a potential across it. These materials are preferred over piezoelectric materials for the utilization of noncontacting methods. Even though carbon fiber–reinforced polymer (CFRP) composite materials are conductors of electricity (Schueler et al., 1997), wires are required to transmit electrical potential to a piezoelectric layer. This complicated wiring is not necessary with a magnetostrictive layer since composite materials tend to be permeable enough for the magnetic potential to penetrate to the magnetostrictive material, allowing the use of noncontacting sensing and excitation coils. This allows structures to be analyzed without the addition of contacting external devices. The sensing and actuation experiments conducted by ETREMA Products, Inc., have proven that Terfenol-D is a valid material for both applications (Butler, 1988). The generalized bulk material numerical models of magnetostrictive rods have been made by ETREMA, the manufacturer of Terfenol-D (Slaughter, 2009). The highly magnetostrictive smart materials have been implemented in a multitude of applications for their ability to become rapidly responding, high-force actuators and as passive defect monitors in composite materials (Wu, 1998).

Numerical modeling of smart materials and structures is often an overlooked step in their development process. Wang et al. (2008) constructed a coupled fourth-rank model of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric materials to capture voltage output characterization of the strain output. Lee et al. (2008) used finite element shell models of magnetostrictive thin films to capture deflections of the magnetostrictive material. Although their method was useful for modeling purposes, it uses the magnetostrictive material as an actuator rather than as a sensor. Yoo et al. (2008) created a three-dimensional fully coupled electromagnetic–mechanical actuator–finite element analysis (FEA) in which the nonlinearity of the magnetostrictive material is considered. When the structural level modeling is incorporated, it is addressed only after lay-ups have been determined, specimens are fabricated, and performance problems are encountered. The models have been researched for patches rather than particulates (Datta et al., 2009; Saidha et al., 2003). Kannan and Dasgupta (1994) developed a finite element program to sense stresses in multifunctional composites using magnetostrictive materials. These models utilized bulk materials instead of particulates. Datta et al. (2008) created a nonlinear magnetomechanical plate model to predict the quasi-static response of a laminated structure with magnetostrictive layers subjected to magnetic fields, and in-plane mechanical axial and shear forces and bending and twisting moments for load-sensing capabilities. This work was not extended to nondestructive methods to determine damage as a result of the loading conditions. A finite element formulation was derived for structural health monitoring of laminated composite beams containing embedded magnetostrictive patches, which will act both as sensors and actuators. The numerical results coordinate actuator and sensor locations with respect to damage locations. While this is a form of embedded-NDE system, the patches themselves are not characterized to determine structural improvement or detraction of the composite laminate (Ghosh and Gopalakrishnan, 2002).

Kumar and Bhattacharya (2008) present a contacting model and experimentation of magnetostrictive-embedded composite laminates with a delamination only on the external surface using an intertwined actuator/sensor. Few results beyond the stacking sequence of the laminate are presented.

Krishnamurthy et al. (2000) conducted experiments coupled with FEA analysis of a CFRP laminate containing a magnetostrictive particle (MSP) layer. The FEA focused only on the formulation of the magnetostrictive material and not on the fully coupled system. This experimental work is very similar to Myers’ experimental work on detecting delaminations in composite structures (Myers and Anjanappa, 2008).

Chen and Anjanappa (2006) have performed experiments comparing results from an analytical and experimental analysis of a composite laminate integrated with the MSPs using a processed thick film, which creates great complexity in the fabrication process. A numerical analysis was also conducted using FEA.

This work details the preliminary studies of a three-part analysis of composite laminates integrated with the MSPs, as a nondestructive, on-demand, health monitor embedded inside the matrix of carbon fiber beams. An analysis was conducted using equations governing the magnetomechanical coupling of Terfenol-D and classical lamination theory. This analysis was performed to begin to characterize the presence of MSPs in a laminate and characterize the predictive amount of strain exhibited by the MSP layer for a given applied magnetic field. The modeling presented in this research characterizes the behavior of embedded particulate magnetostrictive materials with greater consideration for scaling factors. The multiphysics models using linear-coupled equations were used to produce numerical models that coupled alternating current (AC)/direct current (DC) and structural modules to simulate magnetostriction and inverse magnetostriction for Terfenol-D. These models couple the electromagnetomechanical and magnetomechanical behaviors, which provide the foundation for numerical analysis on more complex magnetostrictive-based models. The experimentation was begun by scanning the magnetomechanical coupled laminates. The final form of analysis was an experimental setup using an excitation coil and sensing coil surrounding a composite laminate. The coils were moved along the laminate to determine the change in sensing voltage created by the MSPs.

sec.title: Laminate strengths
sec.p:
The analysis of a magnetomechanical coupled laminate requires the material properties of the sections on the top and bottom of the magnetostrictive film layer to be known. This procedure requires the longitudinal modulus

The B matrix is identical in form to the A matrix. Currently, the authors are conducting tensile, compressive, and bending experiments to determine the level of intrusiveness of the MSPs in various laminates. The magnetostrictive materials are simply assumed to be an additional laminate and the varied property results can be seen later in this article. While the authors realize that the constitutive classical lamination theory is well documented for composite laminates alone, the inclusion of the MSPs coupled with further numerical analysis, and experimental results will validate the presentation of this work at the forefront of the larger body of research. The initial results of the inclusion of the MSPs are presented in the initial results section of this article. The authors also felt it necessary to utilize classical lamination theory even for unidirectional laminates as this will serve as the foundation for future work with cross-ply laminates.

sec.title: Constitutive magnetostrictive theory
sec.p: Magnetostriction is one form of energy conversion from the magnetic domain to the mechanical domain. In 1842, Joule first described the magnetostrictive effect after the observation of a length change of nickel upon the application of an external magnetic field (Pons, 2005). The properties of highly magnetostrictive materials, such as Terfenol-D, have opened the door to a wide variety of application possibilities (Angara et al., 2009; Anjanappa and Wu, 1997; Wu, 1998). One such developing application is the use of MSPs as sensors for determining the structural integrity of composite materials over the course of the operating life. Terfenol-D contains atomic moments that orient themselves within magnetic domains. This results in a strain of 25.4 µm/cm (1 mil/in) of material, when a magnetic force is applied (Jones and Liang, 1996). For magnetostrictive materials to be used as embedded sensors, inverse magnetostriction, also called the Villari effect, must be exploited. The definition of the inverse magnetostriction effect states that if there is a change in the stress or strain of a magnetostrictive material, it will result in a change in its magnetization (Pons, 2005). The constitutive equations of the magnetostrictive material are given as

where

μ

is the permeability at constant stress, and H is the magnetic flux density. From equation (19), it is observed that a magnetic flux density due to an external magnetic field can be introduced by either mechanically stressing
( σ )
, the material, applying a magnetic field (H) or both. A coupled actuation is used by first prestressing the material during fabrication then applying a magnetic field to strain the material such that the embedded material experiences additional stress through the resistance of the laminate. For the initial model, the focus is on the application of the magnetic field reducing equation (19) to

sec.title: Stress in the magnetostrictive material
sec.p: The magnetomechanical relationship for the magnetostrictive material is nonlinear and dependent on the amount of prestress being applied to the material. This relationship can be seen in Figure 1, where the strain as a function of magnetic field is plotted for various prestress levels.

caption.p: Strain versus magnetic field (Butler, 1988).

sec.p: Based upon the research conducted by Myers and Anjanappa (2008), a compressive prestress is applied to the laminate during fabrication and the MSPs experience an indeterminate statics condition that inhibits any strain when the magnetostrictive material experiences a magnetic field.

sec.title: Induced voltage
sec.p: Similar to how the application of a magnetic field to the magnetostrictive layer induces strain, the stress induced in the layer by the composite laminate causes a magnetic field to be given off by the magnetostrictive layer as referenced in equation (19). This magnetic field induces a voltage in the sensing coil, and it is a function of stress and the applied magnetic field as derived in equations (27) and (28). As seen in Figure 2, the permeability of the magnetostrictive layer is nonlinear but has a linear central region. For this research, the values are assumed to be linear. The values for the permeability and magnetic threshold for discontinuity as a function of prestress are given in Table 1.

caption.p: Permeability of the magnetostrictive layer (Butler, 1988).
Permeability constants for prestress conditions (Krishnamurthy et al., 2000).

sec.title: Preliminary two-dimensional modeling of the Terfenol-D magnetostrictive particle layer
sec.p: Due to the magnetomechanical coupling of the magnetostrictive material, structural mechanics and AC/DC electrical modules were used as the foundation to generate the preliminary models. The first model presented is a two-dimensional model (Figure 3) that allows the coil to be rotated about a central axis. The dimensions of the overall Terfenol-D layer 7.75-in long and 0.012-in thick. It is located 0.25-in away from the coil, which has dimensions of 0.1 in × 0.25 in. There is no delamination in this model because it served as an initial test model. The x-axis represents the radial direction and the y-axis represents the longitudinal direction of the beam. The small box titled R30 is the coil domain. The other notated domains are initial attempts to create smaller and smaller MSPs rather than a thin film layer. The preliminary models were made to verify the electromagnetic and magnetomechanical coupled behavior. Three-dimensional models are being created to more accurately simulate the geometries and the experimental setup. This model has 10,351 elements, 5517 nodes, and 64,152 degrees of freedom. The minimum element quality is 0.792/1. The run time was 15 s. The magnetomechanical properties for the numerical models are re-defined by the linear-coupled magnetostrictive equations in the stress-field form (Claeyssen et al., 1994; Slaughter, 2009). The input current applied to the subdomain for the coil was 434 A/m2 in the Azimuthal direction of the coil. The discretized Terfenol-D layer was located on the line of axisymmetry. The air and Terfenol-D layer have a continuity boundary layer condition that allows the field generated by the coil to interact with the magnetostrictive layer. The boundary of the air domain has magnetic insulation. Each boundary of the Terfenol-D subdomain is fixed to the next boundary. Tables 2 and 3 show the magnetostrictive and laminate properties as input into the COMSOL FEA software for this analysis

caption.p: Initial finite element models to simulate magnetostrictive particulates: (a) model consists of magnetostrictive sections to simulate particles, coil, and farfield air; and (b) flux density results.
Magnetostrictive Terfenol-D material properties as entered into finite element analysis software.
Material properties of AS4/3501-6 composites used for this study.

sec.p:
where
σ
is the stress,
c
B
is the compliance matrix, S is the strain, h and
h
t
are the magnetostrictive coupling coefficient, H is the magnetic field, B is the magnetic flux density, and
γ
B
is the inverse of permeability. The controlling parameters for these models are the current amplitude, frequency, and the number of Terfenol-D subdivisions or subdomains, which were used to approximate particulates rather than a thin film layer. Several models were produced to observe the affects of increasing the number of divisions in the Terfenol-D layer to simulate a particulate actuating layer. All models have a 0.005-in-thick MSP layer surrounded by a copper coil to simulate current flow in the perpendicular axis. The coil is set to deliver an AC with a magnitude of 7 mA and has an area of approximately 0.16 cm2 (0.25 in2). The current induces a magnetic field that causes the Terfenol-D to strain. A postprocessed plot displayed in Figure 3 shows the magnetic flux density magnitudes as a surface plot. The largest flux density is seen in the Terfenol-D as a result of the high magnetic permeability.

The simplified analytical equations that are being used to validate the numerical results are displayed in the following (Serway and Jewett, 2004). Equation (33) describes the proportional relationship between the flux density and the radius of the inner coil
R
. Equation (34) accounts for the inversely proportional relationship between the flux density and the radius outside of the coil,
r
. These equations are for symmetric geometries. To obtain this trend analytically, Amperes law is applied in a piecewise manner along with a magnetostrictive equation

A preliminary three-dimensional finite element models was created to couple the magnetomechanical effects of the CFRP-embedded laminate and to highlight the delamination as shown in Figures 4 and 5. The representative magnetostrictive material is placed as the central laminate and set as 4.5 cm (1.75 in) from each end of the beam. The delamination is modeled as a 0.5 in × 0.5 in patch that has negligible stiffness by making the modulus small (E = 0.001 Pa). The model consists of 315,991 elements, 53,332 nodes, and 4,125,148 degrees of freedom. The overall minimum element quality was 0.0571/1. An excitation coil is modeled with the cross-sectional area of a 700-turn coil and has an input voltage of 30 V at the input port. A ground was set up on the opposing end of the coil and the domain served as the path for the current. All interior boundaries have magnetic continuity. The air boundary has magnetic insulation. An iterative FGMRES/Vanka solver (COMSOL 4.1, 2010, Structural Mechanics Module) was used due to the high degree of freedom. The model is time-harmonic. The run time was 4 days for 710 iterations.

caption.p: Three-dimensional geometry model highlighting the embedded magnetostrictive material layer.
Three-dimensional geometry model highlighting the forced delamination.

sec.p:
The preliminary results show the variation in the magnetization and strain that highlights the location of the delamination in Figures 6 and 7 showing promise of modeling capabilities in detecting internal delamination. The forced 0.5-in2 delamination for this model is centralized in the 250 mm × 2.5 mm × 1.5 mm beam. The normalized magnetic field of Figure 6 shows a variation of
1 . 499 ×
10
7
A / m
to
3 . 641 ×
10
7
A / m
at the position of the delamination. The strain plot in Figure 7 is induced by the magnetic field and the resistance of the laminates to the strain. The strain plot highlights the initial perimeter of the forced delamination in the laminate. These results offer great promise to the use of magnetostrictive materials as a damage sensor in composite laminates. Furthermore, numerical mathematics is necessary to correlate the normalized magnetic field results to the output voltage described in the analytical models and the experimental results.

caption.p: Comparison of magnetization of laminate with and without delamination.
Localized strain plot near the perimeter of delamination.

sec.title: Sensor configuration
sec.p: The sensor is comprises two concentric coils (excitation and sensing) of 38 AWG magnet wire wrapped around Delrin bobbins. The excitation coil is wrapped with approximately 700 turns and the sensing coil is wrapped with approximately 200 turns (Myers, 1996; Myers and Anjanappa, 2008). The shape of the bobbins matches the rectangular shapes of the beams. The sensing coil is concentrically positioned inside the excitation coil to obtain output readings. The purpose of the excitation coil is to produce a sinusoidal magnetic field that would excite the MSPs so that the sensing coil could detect the induced voltage from the magnetic field. The sensor is assembled as shown in Figure 8. The wire coils were wound around their respective rectangular bobbins and the wires were soldered to their respective terminals on the connection plate secured to the sensor. This was performed to prevent any loose or intermittent connection issues.

caption.p: Solid model and subassemblies of sensing coil.

sec.title: Experimental apparatus configuration
sec.p: The purpose of this experimental setup is to develop an on-demand apparatus capable of detecting a defect inside a composite beam that may be feasible in the field. The experimental apparatus as shown in Figure 9 consisted of a pair of aluminum stands and guide rods that support the sample composite beam and allow the sensor to move freely along the length of the beam. The sensor terminals are then connected directly to a LabVIEW PXI controller (National Instruments, NI PXIe-8135). Three LabVIEW cards were used in this experiment: NI PXI-4461 data acquisition card, NI PXI-5421 analog waveform generator, and NI PXI-4071 multimeter. The excitation coil was connected to the analog waveform generator, programmed to output the sinusoidal voltage signal. The pickup coil was then hooked to the data acquisition card, which collected the signal generated by the excited MSPs. The multimeter was used to record the input root mean square (RMS) voltage and input amperage before each test. Finally, a LabVIEW virtual instrument (VI) was developed.

caption.p: Experimental setup.

sec.p: The primary functions of the VI (Figure 10) developed are to produce a sinusoidal voltage signal in the excitation coil and to calculate the RMS voltage induced in the sensing coil. These primary functions are achieved through a collection of sub-VIs running in conjunction with the main instrument. One sub-VI is dedicated to monitoring the voltage in the sensing coil and is responsible for returning the raw voltage data, fast Fourier transform, and RMS value of the voltage of the sensing coil. Developing an instrument that could be used in the field is a milestone toward real-time data acquisition, analysis and ultimately, structural health management/monitoring. The snapshot recording function allows the user to set the number of places along the beam to be sampled and set to the number of samples per location. The sensor is moved to various locations and the data are recorded allowing the user to easily find and record the data at points of interest. This instrument was used to produce all of the results presented in this work.

caption.p: LabVIEW virtual instrument system excitation and data acquisition system.

sec.title: Fabrication
sec.p:
The priority of the fabrication methods developed was to design easily implemented, cost-effective processes for embedding MSPs into a composite beam (Spayde et al., 2011). Selecting a unidirectional carbon fiber prepreg as the composite material allowed for a minimal fabrication setup. The layup sequence and ply orientation of
[
0
6
/ M /
0
6
]
refers to six plies of unidirectional fibers oriented along the length of the beam sandwiching a single layer of MSPs. The molds were designed to achieve the specified geometry of the composite beam. Each mold was capable of applying a uniform compressive stress to the beam during the curing process. Figure 4 shows the final design of the molds used in this work. The base plate is a flat surface so that the prepreg may be pressed by roller to ensure proper bonding between layers. The top plate is used to apply uniform stress during the curing process mentioned earlier. The four side plates are designed to be mounted directly to the base plate to minimize flashing.

The beams were fabricated beginning with a non-MSP control beam of
[
0
13
]
. This beam was used to show that there was no noticeable difference between an empty sensor and a sensor examining a carbon fiber beam without embedded MSPs. The first and simplest method used to embed MSPs into the composite matrix began by laying the first six plies into the mold. Next, MSPs ranging from 212 to 300 µm were introduced into the mold. A set volume of 1.15 g of MSPs was manually distributed along the beam. The MSP layer was spread by hand as evenly as possible approximately 4.5 cm (1.75 in) from each end of the mold. Figure 5 shows the location of the MSPs inside of the beam. This was performed in order to observe the transition from no MSPs to MSPs. Using this method, an assumed defect-free MSP-embedded control beam was made. To create the delaminations, small strips of Teflon and parchment paper ranging in size from 116in2 to 12in×1in were placed in between the MSP layer and one side of the prepreg ply. From this lot of samples, a first round of experiments was conducted to establish the proof of concept and initial trends.

After initial experiments were conducted, two improved fabrication methods attempt to take advantage of the highly controlled amount of resin within the composite prepreg. The objective of these two methods was to limit or remove possible fabrication errors created when spreading the MSPs by hand. Knowing that the amount of resin was highly controlled allowed the uniform adhesion of the prepreg to be exploited. These methods use the uniform adhersion of the prepreg to attempt to evenly adhere the MSPs onto the laminate. The goal of the first method was to adhere the maximum amount of MSPs to the laminate. This was achieved by dispersing the MSPs along the beam and by applying sufficient pressure to the MSPs and prepreg. Afterward, the mold was turned over, with the laminate remaining in place, to allow the excess MSPs to leave the mold. This process was repeated multiple times to ensure maximum MSP coverage. It is important to note that the beams created with this method used a layup sequence of
[
0
x
/ M /
0
x
]
. This was performed to conserve material while creating an early proof of concept. The final method presented in this work follows a similar procedure, the differences being that the MSP is only dispersed once and that the pressure applied is much lower. This was done in order to see whether the amount of MSPs embedded could be controlled by the applied force, while remaining in a uniform distribution.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
For initial analytical modeling, only the extensional stiffness was calculated to characterize the laminates. The model combined the classical lamination theory and magnetostrictive material theory previously discussed for the following laminates:

, and

. The extensional stiffnesses (
A
α β σ γ
) from the preliminary analytical models indicate that the extensional stiffness of the embedded magnetostrictive particulates
[
0
6
/ m /
0
6
]
is between the extensional stiffness of the
[

and
[
0

]
laminates in the primary direction of the fibers. The calculated values from equations (15) and (17) for the extensional stiffness are listed in equation (35). This offers an initial indication that the presence of the MSPs is minimally intrusive in the laminate structure in tension. Furthermore, numerical modeling and experimental tensile tests are required to validate these initial models and values. As an extension of this work, the bending and torsional experiments, and simulations must be conducted

The signal sent from the analog waveform generator to the excitation coil was a sinusoidal voltage with peak amplitude of 5 V at a frequency of 1200 Hz (Anjanappa et al., 1999; Chen and Anjanappa, 2006; Myers and Anjanappa, 2008). At each location along the beam, several data points were collected. The plots in this section show the average RMS voltage, as calculated by the VI, in the sensing coil at each of these locations along the beam. The initial test performed in this experiment was to validate that a carbon fiber composite had little to no effect on the sensor. This was tested by running the sensor over the
[
0
13
]
ply composite beam. The results from this test, shown in Figure 11, compare the average sensor reading without a beam, to the sensor reading at 19 points, every ½ in, along the
[
0
13
]
beam. The sensor signal with the control beam in place averages 0.213917 V, the same as the sensor without a beam. Also the points shown here are all within the empty sensors with a standard deviation of 0.0000011 V.

caption.p: No MSP control beam and average empty sensor reading.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.

sec.p:
The next set of tests used the beams in which the MSPs were distributed by hand. First, the
[
0
6
/ M /
0
6
]
MSP control beam was tested. The results from this test (Figure 12) show inconsistencies with this fabrication method. This lack of consistency is most likely due to inconsistencies in the MSP distribution. This suggests that the amount of MSP in any given area of the composite heavily influences the sensors’ output voltage as shown in Figure 12.

caption.p: Control beam with MSPs distributed by hand.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.

sec.p: In order to further examine this behavior, a second beam was tested that was fabricated in a similar manner. The differences in this beam include ply orientation, although still the same number of plies, and two 0.5 in × 0.5 in delaminations were introduced at 3.5 and 6.5 in. At first glance of Figure 13, it appears as if one of the delaminations was detected properly. However, the signal as a whole is once again inconsistent with the characteristics of the beam. This leads to the belief that the increase in voltage found between 5 and 7.5 in is the result of a collection of MSPs rather than an increase in MSP strain, due to the delamination. Even with some initial inconsistencies, the beams were fabricated with more consistent results as presented.

caption.p: Delamination beam with MSPs distributed by hand.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.

sec.p: Figure 14 shows the configuration and scanning results of an experimental CFRP beam with delaminations that were introduced during fabrication. The darkened area shows the location of the magnetostrictive material. The experimental approach was to scan the length graphite–epoxy beams with the damage introduced with Teflon tape at denoted positions. Figure 14 shows the sensor position and voltage output of the scans of a graphite beam with 116-in-wide delaminations of lengths ⅛, ½, and 1¼ in. Note the variation of the voltages at locations 4, 5, and 6 of the scans as 3.106, 3.039, and 3.031 V, respectively. A similar trend was noticed for beams embedded with ⅛-in-wide delaminations in Figure 15 with voltage outputs of 3.059, 3.035, and 3.02 for lengths of ⅛, ½, and 1¼ in, respectively. For the CFRP beam embedded shown in Figure 16 with ¼-in-wide delaminations, the trend of decreasing voltage with increasing delamination length reversed with voltage readouts for ½- and 1¼-in lengths of 3.004 and 3.031 V, respectively. While the initial trend follows traditional mechanics of smaller stress concentrations, yielding higher voltage readouts, the data for the 1¼-in-wide delaminations counters that trend. A similar counter point is shown in Figure 17 with voltages of 3.008 and 3.016 for delaminations of ½ and 1¼ in, respectively. This variation could be attributed to an increased volume of the MSPs at the 1¼-in-wide delaminations. More experimentation is necessary to ensure consistent particulate distribution during fabrication and consistent delamination sizing.

caption.p: Voltage scans of beam with 116-in delaminations.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.
Voltage scans of beam with ⅛-in delaminations.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.
Voltage scans of beam with ¼-in delaminations.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.
Voltage scans of beam with ½-in delaminations.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.

sec.p:
Improving upon the original fabrication method was the goal of the second set of beams. These beams were created as a secondary proof of concept and lack the same number of plies,
[
0
2
/ M /
0
2
]
, as the rest of the beams. Figure 18 shows the results from the first of these beams. This is a no-defect control beam embedded with the MSPs using the adhering method previously described. As such, the expected results from this test are a constant voltage from 2.5 to 7.5 in. We can see in Figure 18 that the consistency of the voltage over the embedded area has improved greatly. The mean voltage from 2.5 to 7.5 in is 0.22077 V.

caption.p: Control beam with MSPs distributed by adhesion.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.

sec.p: With the previous test showing much promise, the next beam test was made in the same fashion with a single 0.5 in × 0.5 in delamination located at the 5-in mark. As with previous first lot fabrication beams, the MSP-embedded area of the beam is again fairly consistent. This consistency is appropriate except in the center of the beam, where the delamination is located; there should be a delta in the voltage at this location. The data collected show no appreciable change in the voltage across the delamination. Upon further inspection of the beam after testing was completed, the hypothesized problem was that the MSPs embedded within the beam had forced a ply separation along the entire length of the embedding area. This, in fact, created a very large delamination that eclipsed the original manufactured delamination from the sensor. This resulted in the sensor reporting an approximately consistent voltage.

The last set of beams in this work was fabricated with a process based on the adhesive method. The theory was that by controlling the amount of force used to compress the MSPs to the prepreg, one could control the amount of MSPs that would adhere to the prepreg. This was also an attempt to reduce the amount of MSPs between plies in order to prevent another MSP-induced delamination. Figure 19 shows the results from the no-defect control beam fabricated with this method. The average voltage across the embedded area is 0.22013 V with a standard deviation of 0.000327 V. This is a similar average voltage as the previous method but with an improved standard deviation. Using the previous set of tests as a basis, these results suggest that the MSPs forced another large delamination and that the beam still contained too much MSPs, or that the size of the MSP is too large for the amount of resin in the prepreg.

caption.p: Delamination beam with MSPs distributed by controlled adhesion.
MSP: magnetostrictive particle.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The authors present preliminary and ongoing research on the coupled magnetomechanics of embedded MSPs in composite laminates for nondestructive evaluation of the laminates. The work described in this article is part of a three-tiered analysis approach including baseline analytical models, coupled FEA, and ongoing experimental work. The analytical models characterize the tensile laminate properties and will be further expanded to account for bending and bend-extension characteristics. The extensive tensile testing is required for laminates of various thicknesses to validate the current analytical model. The FEA constructs a model that incorporates a carbon fiber laminate embedded with a Terfenol-D layer and delaminations, which will allow analysis of the magnetomechanical parameters. The numerical analysis investigates the effects of the controlling parameters on the magnetic flux density signature of the Terfenol-D layer. The controlling parameters were the current amplitude, current frequency, and the number of Terfenol-D divisions. The experiments were performed using Terfenol-D-embedded carbon fiber laminates with delaminations. Many details emerged that demonstrated some of the complications of implementing such a system. The MSPs must be evenly distributed throughout the composite, as collections of these particles will increase the sensors’ RMS voltage, resulting in a false reading. Another issue was that the MSPs can force a delamination along the entire embedded area. Two primary causes of this behavior are too much MSPs between the plies and using particles sizes that are too large. Going forward with this research, the methods that distribute MSPs evenly, such as the complex magnetostrictive thick films (Chen and Anjanappa, 2006), will become a priority, as will smaller particle sizes. The results obtained from this research will be used to form a foundation and further the research for developing a novel embedded-NDE system using MSPs.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research was partially funded by the MSU Raspet Flight Center Research Grant and MSU Research Initiation Grant.
